title: How many people in the US will have received one or more doses of a COVID-19 vaccine as of 30 April 2021, according to the CDC?
preds: A strong Friday 30th number look to be the decider. More than 1.35m doses given tomorrow could push the total over the 150m mark. Congratulations to all those involved in getting this many vaccinations given.
The crowd is all in for 140-150M.  It looks to me like the answer is very close to 150M -- I'll split my chips.  But the crowd is probably right, so I won't bet too heavily against it.
In the end, it will be 149.x m, but apparently not 150. May get pretty close though.
Changing forecast to reflect current information
https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccination-trends . One day left so there's a very little uncertainty
Interestingly, rate of 1st dose administration < rate of 2nd dose and this doesn't bode well for overall vaccination coverage. Adjusting the brackets in question by 10%.

There are currently 142.7M individuals that have received 1 or more doses with only 48 hours to go.  The likelihood of that number increasing is incredibly low given that only 2M were added the past 2 days.
About 141 million on 26 April, approximately 5 million more since 22 April. At this rate, there would be about 146 million by 30 April.

This one’s still on the knife’s edge.
In the past, the day plus 3 (April 30 from today) wound up with a final number roughly 8.5m higher than the day minus 1.
Day minus 1 = April 26 = 141751857
141.8m + 8.5m = 150.3m Going slightly up to 55% for > 150m
Similar to full vaccination numbers, the pace here hasn't picked up and now 140-150 seems the more likely bucket.

4/27: 141.8M. Effectively ~6 more days of reporting. If 1.5M people/day added, then total will be 141.8M + ~1.5M * 6 = 150.8. But over the past week, 1.26M/day have been added. 141.8M + ~1.26M * 6 = 149.4M. And, vaccination rates are falling. I don't see any way this total will be >= 150M.
Prediction: "Daily Change Reported" in vaccinations reported tomorrow 4/28 will be <2.5M.
4/28: 142.7M. 0.9M added. Daily Change Reported was ~2.25M, about 0.25M less than the same day last week.
4/29: 143.8M. 1.1M added. Daily Change Reported was ~2.75M, about 0.25M less than the same day last week. Total by April 30 will likely be between 147M and 148M.

While it could be very close, it now looks more likely to miss the 150K threshold. Even with a sharp increase over the final few days the trend looks to hit between 1.0-1.25M/day. I'm forecasting around 148.5M
Forecast range 146.5-150.5M.

There are currently 140.97M individuals in the US that have received 1 or more doses.  This number has been increasing about 1.5M per day.  With only 4 days left, the likelihood of reaching 150M people is low.

Reconsidering how many days to include for back reporting. 
A straight linear forecast based on adding 8.8M people in the past week (1.26M/day) + 3 additional days for back reporting yields 140.0M +  1.26M * 8 = 150.1M, *right* on the line. But I do expect fewer people to be vaccinated this week than last. So I will still go with a stronger chance of the lower bin.

The population of vaccination is increasing steadily. Although there are people who is suspicious in inoculating the covid vaccine, there are only 42.9% of the population received at least one dose. There is still spaces for the population in receiving vaccines to grow.

The rolling weekly number has dipped below 9 m, which makes the avg daily number ~ 1.3. THIS RATE won't help in getting to 150 in 4/5 days. Yet there is still a good chance because, there can easily be a couple of 2 m days. Also the number dipping below 9 should suggest just SOME measure of mean reversion in the next day or two.

A straight linear forecast based on adding 8.8M people in the past week (1.26M/day) + 2 additional days for back reporting gets to 148.8M < 150M. But I expect fewer people to be vaccinated this week than last. There seem to be a lot of vaccination opportunities around the country that are going untaken. That pushes my forecast firmly <150M.

This one seems to be impossible to predict between 140-150 and 150-160.
Going  50:50 for now.
I don't know what I was thinking with that one. Changed forecast based on making weird forecast previously.
Looks like the 5 day average is less than a million. it was less than 5 million for two 5 days periods before that. going all in on less than 150,000,000

This is starting to look like a close call.  I had previously expected that opening the vaccine to a wider age group mid-April would gradually increase uptake but of course that is only the case if the wider population is inclined to do so. Valid comments from @belikewater and @bruce-duggan and others also corroborate that numbers are more likely to be lower due to negative coverage of J&J and AstraZeneca, plus vaccine hesitancy and disinterest particularly among younger age groups. Supply is clearly not the issue.
After initially feeling confident at 153-160M I now expect a range of 147-151M

While the number of people with at least one dose is still increasing significantly per day, it seems unlikely that the trend will reach 150,000,000 by Friday, since it appears to be around 140,000,000 right now, since the trend has slowed.

Lots of appointments available.
https://twitter.com/bhrenton/status/1386387329347198985
About 3M fewer doses administered reported for past week than the week before.
4/25: 140.0M people who have received at least one dose. 4/18: 131.2M. 140.0M - 131.2M = 8.8M increase in past week. 140.0M + 8.8M (inc. 2 days for delayed reporting) = 148.8M. Later edit:
An article about Michigan, just one state among many, of course:
"After months in which a frenzy for vaccines far exceeded the state’s limited supply, officials are beginning to see a softening in demand, with weekly vaccination numbers in parts of the state beginning to slacken." "“We've kind of hit all those people who wanted it, who were fighting to get their vaccines, who were jumping in front of everyone else,” said Sarah Oleniczak, deputy health officer at District Health Department, which covers 10 central Michigan counties." "At the beginning, a mass vaccination clinic with appointments for 1,300 would draw that many and more. But on a recent Saturday, he said, “we had the capacity to do 1,300, and we ended up doing about 800.”" "And when he arrived at a small church clinic recently, “everyone was sort of sitting around. Nobody was really doing any vaccinating.” Mukkamala flipped open his Facebook page: We have extra vaccines, he posted. “We got another maybe 20 people to come in,” he said. “If I had I done the exact same thing in January, my phone would have blown up, and everybody and their brother would have shown up."" "Certainly, enthusiasm for vaccines has not flagged everywhere. Oakland County officials continue to work through a waiting list of more than 150,000"
https://www.bridgemi.com/michigan-health-watch/michigan-covid-vaccine-rates-ebb-pop-clinics-and-casino-cash-appear
Going down a little bit (140-150m: 0>15%); still expecting 150m+, next days will not really show, might be a foto finish.

Lots of appointments available.
https://twitter.com/bhrenton/status/1386387329347198985 About 3M fewer doses administered reported for past week than the week before.
Apr 19 had 135.3M so need 1.34M/day to reach 150M. 7 day moving average is 1.3M and falling fast. I think this is going to come in under 150M
I don't see the increase in the vaccination rate even after the pause on J&J being lifted. This suggests people may be hesitant in taking J&J. Will check back in a couple of days.

Update: Currently 138.6M. On 4/17, 129.5M. In the past 7 days, 9.1M / 7 = 1.3M/day added. 1.3M * 8 days (including a couple extra for delayed reporting) = 10.4M more. 138.6M + 10.4M = 149.0M. It really depends also on how many days one allows for back reporting. If 2 days covers it, then we'll probably end up in bin 3. Also, vaccine administration seems to be slowing, which also favors bin 3. J&J vaccination starts up again, but that shouldn't affect this number much, if at all. Vaccine availability is not currently the bottleneck.
Rate slowed down, but reintroduction of J&J makes the middle bucket (150-160) a bit more likely.

12.8m to go to 150m with 6 days.  This is 2.1m per day.  If add 3m for the reporting lag then 1.6m needed per day. Average now down to 1.4m and needs to recover a long way to make 150m.  Will get 140m but not 150m.

Update 4/23: Currently 137.2M. On 4/17, 129.5M. In the past 6 days, 7.7M / 6 = ~1.3M/day added. 7.7M / 6 * 9 days (including a couple extra for delayed reporting) = ~11M to 12M more. 137M + 11M = 148M; 137M + 12M = 149M. But tomorrow is a higher reporting day, so this is probably skewed slightly low. To reach 150M, need to add somewhere between 1.28M and 1.4M/day. It's very close between bins 3 and 4, and unexpectedly low to me.
We are definitely already hitting vaccine hesitancy and probably also just disinterest.
adjusting forecast due to passage of time

Rate is slowing slightly as:
1: vaccine-hesitant make up increasingly large proportion of the unvaccinated (people who have decided "no" or "likely no" who haven't changed their minds yet are unlikely to change their minds)
2: rare-negative effects will continue to get much more media coverage than common-neutral and common-positive effects (people who are undecided now are likely to be swayed by media coverage)
3: easy-to-access vaccination candidates make up increasingly small proportion of the unvaccinated (increasing effort required to access each potential vaccine recipient slows rate)
4: medical system will increasingly prefer to administer 2nd shots to the willing over convincing the reluctant or accessing the hard-to-reach for their first short)

Watching the reporting delays carefully.  There does seem to be a slight slowdown in vaccinations at the moment, but I expect the 7 day Moving Average to maintain a 1.5 - 1.7 million doses per day over the coming fortnight.
There vaccinetes circa 2 millions of new people with minimum one doses each day. That would mean that it´s near than 150 millions on april 30th

17.7m to go to 150m with 9 days.  This is 1.9m per day.  If add 3m for the reporting lag then 1.6m. rates don’t look like they will recover that quickly.  Last 4 fully reported average well under 1.6m.  Upping forecast for below 150m

Erase and rewind...
In the past two days, the 160m+ trajectory dissipated
I humbly return to the wisdom of the crowd

My estimate for the full-vaccination assumed a base rate 9m/week + push (due to open season for everyone), so to be consistent, I should expect about 18m until Apr 30 for 1st dose. Of course J&J pause doesn't help, however it's reasonable to think- number of  1st doses > number of 2nd doses for the next few weeks. Hence I had put greater weight for 150-160 bracket than I had while forecasting full vaccinate rate.
First prediction was way off as I misread the question.

Update. Looking more likely that the number will be <= ~155M.
My previous calculations that we are close to saturating vaccine demand were completely wrong, though. We are *not* close to the limit. As @CJH pointed out, I had the wrong population age 16+; it's actually ~264M. If 25%-30% refuse a vaccine, then ~185M-198M will ultimately be vaccinated.

Hm...still going against the crowd here. Look at April 11, for instance:
Vaccinated: 123.9m 
7 day average (April 5 to April 11) daily increase: 1,865m
Days left: 19
Forecast for April 30: 123.9 + 1.865 x 19= 159.3m
And then, until May 9, more data will be reported for the past. 
Unless something unexpected slows down the vaccination campaign, it is still aiming at 160m+

18.8m needed to get to 150m which is an average of 1.7m per day.  Assuming reporting lag has 3m people this moves the needed average to 1.45m. 
J&J pause could drop the rate of 1st vaccines by up to 20pc for 1st doses for a period, which directly impacts this question. This is likely to bring the average back closer to where it was a few weeks ago which was still at 1.6m.  But is the 20pc reduction from the 1.8m of last few days or that 1.6m? 20pc drop on 1.8m is 1.4m, so bringing close to the threshold.
https://eu.usatoday.com/in-depth/graphics/2021/04/17/how-johnson-johnson-pause-due-blood-clots-could-slow-vaccines/7243236002/ Daily average already dipped a lot and today’s rate is a lot lower than this time last week, so expect it to drop again in coming days.
Have to consider that 150m will not be reached.  Putting small pc on 140 to 150 range, and need to monitor.

Considerations:
- https://polymarket.com/market/will-150-million-people-have-received-a-dose-of-an-approved-covid-19-vaccine-in-the-us-by-may-1-2021 has 47% above 150M by May 1, but checked on morning May 1, so should treat this as 47% above ~155M due to data lag.
- According to https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccination-trends, number was 125.2M as of Apr 12. Projecting at 1.8M per day for 18 days gives 157.6M, which is pretty close to Polymarket. Actually 1.8M per day might be an overestimate due to J&J being paused. So my median is ~154M. Thinking about the bins:
- To get under 150M, we'd have to administer under 1.4M per day which seems unlikely but possible due to J&J stoppage and one other surprise. I'll give it 8%.
- To get above 160M, we'd have to administer ~1.95M per day which seems more plausible but still unlikely to rise that much due to J&J stoppage. I'll give it 12%.

Just looking at the trajectory, it still looks like 160m+. However, 
-	if vaccination efforts reach a ceiling because now it also needs to convince the hesitant part of the opulation
-	as an increasing share of the doses seem to be administered as second doses
the curve may slow down in the second half of the month. 
150m+ : 20% > 30% 
160m+:  80% > 70%

According with this page 1, the U.S. has administered approximate 200M initial and complete  doses of a COVID-19 vaccine. So we can think that the vaccination rate of U.S is 2.5 M people per day according with 2.  In this case, we can think that the number of people will have received one or more doses of vaccine is approximate 230M until 30 April 2021.  But if we think that the system is not perfect, in my opinion, the number will be between 170M and 180M (probably). 1. https://time.com/collection/coronavirus-vaccines-updates/
2. https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2021/01/28/960901166/how-is-the-covid-19-vaccination-campaign-going-in-your-state

The J&J problem does not seem to slow down vaccination efforts.
Projections now reach  roughly 158 million, roughly 5m more than a week ago. 
Kinda agressive, but I am changing
150-160: 75% > 35%
160-170: 25% > 65%
Average up over 1.8m and need to account for the 5 day reporting lag.
Same rationale as April 9th but marginally higher numbers than predicted for last week push forecast range towards upper end at 158.5-161.5M

There are currently 127.8M individuals in the US that have received one or more COVID vaccines.  The US' current vaccine distribution rate is 3M per day. https://www.cnbc.com/2021/04/16/covid-19-cases-deaths-vaccinations-daily-update.html With 2 weeks left in this month:
127.8M * (3M*14 days) = 169.8M (high end with each dose going to a new person)
127.8M * (1.5M*14 days) = 148.8 M (low end with each person receiving full dose amount)
Simple math based on current vaccination rates, which are accelerating.

Same as last time, except assuming CDC has substantially less than the total sum until four days later.  ~1.7m*15+125 822 867=152 005 847.  I believe this number is inflated!  The US is halting use of Johnson and Johnson!  Which would affect totals just shy of ~7m.  Though, with resources eventually diverted from Johns and Astraz, we can expect it to be more, possibly sooner.

Gottlieb also sees 150 million as a potential ceiling. https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2021/04/14/987265125/ex-fda-chief-sees-struggle-to-vaccinate-more-than-half-u-s-population?utm_term=nprnews&utm_campaign=npr&utm_source=facebook.com&utm_medium=social

Assumption: As at 9th May, modelling shows reference figure for 1st April 'First Doses given' to be approx 107.2 million.
Using 107.2 million on 1st April as starting reference point.

124m today.  
15 days to go.  Average of 1.7m per day = 25.5m extra = 149.5m
140m threshold = 16m = 1.07m per day
150m threshold = 26m = 1.73m per day Could be close around 150m threshold, but punting on the above 150m mark.

Update 4/17: Forecast is holding, as we appear to be increasingly hitting a saturation of vaccine demand.
In the past week, 129.5M - 114.4M = 15.1M people added who are fully vaccinated. But, just over ~3M doses/day * 7 days = ~21M vaccine doses administered; that means 0.72 * the doses administered = people receiving first dose. That's higher than before; the long term average has been ~64%. I don't understand this, because there was also seemingly a greater fraction devoted to people being fully vaccinated. It can't all be J&J.
So: ~8.8M more doses for this week + 2 weeks at ~3.25M/day and ~3.4M/day = 55.4M more doses administered in the forecast period. So, around, say, 54M to 58M more doses administered by April 30.
0.72 * 55.4M = ~40M more people who have received at least one dose.
129.5M to date + ~40M more = 169.5M, with significant error bars.
But before we reach 169M, we'll probably saturate demand. Also, not everyone who says they want a vaccine will necessarily arrive at a vaccine appointment.
Update 4/19: As of 4/18, number is 131.2M. So, 1.7M added in 1 day. Equivalent to about 14 more days (accounting for delayed reporting) * 1.7M/day (ballpark) = 24M more. 131M + 24M = 155M. Forecast still holding.

Assumption based on current modelling: 
If - Tally for 30th April as at 30th April = X
Then - Tally for 30th of April as showing on the 9th May AM (GMT)  =  X  + 7.3million

~1 million/day.  18 days.  Currently, 120 million.  120+18=138 million.  Expect acceleration.  Expect undelivered doses to get used soon.  Higher values are likely.  Production accelerations divided between entire world, resulting in small net increases.  Actual use slightly higher than 1million/day.  Second doses eating first dose supplies.  Total output not expected to miraculously multiply overnight.

We are at about 118M  now, and probably adding 2M to per day.  With 20 days, level that gets us to 158M.  We could run into supply issues are vaccine hesitancy here. But likely, we will continue tracking as we are now.
120,000,000 today plus approximately 1,700,000 per day which comes to 154,000,000 total.

Update.
Without vaccine hesitancy, I think we'd expect 162M-165M to have received at least one vaccine dose by the end of the forecast period.
With vaccine hesitancy of 25%-30%, a total of 151M-163M would be vaccinated.
I don't know what the error bars on the vaccine hesitancy estimates are. And another possibility is that some people may not be vaccinated right away because of some other factor.
I suspect that closer to 30% of the US population age 16+ will not be vaccinated in the short term. So I have to assign greater weight to the 150M to 160M bin.

114.5m today.  
20 days to go.  Average of 1.65m per day = 33m extra = 147.5m
140m threshold = 26m = 1.3m per day
150m threshold = 36m = 1.7m per day Average has been between 1.6 and 1.7m for a couple of weeks but showing a little drop off.  But wouldn’t take much increase to go over 150m. Rationale from @Ryan-Beck shows vaccine hesitancy and proportion of 1st to 2nd doses need to be taken into account. Got burnt in previous months forecasts by not envisaging and uptick in delivery so going to listen to the crowd more about likely to be higher than I think, although I am puzzled how so many think the forecast will be so high.

Update: I think we'd definitely get to the 160M to 170M bin except for the possibility of vaccine hesitancy. Rethinking that a bit, I think there's some chance this total will be under 160M. Population 16+ is about 217M. Currently, ~25% of this population plans to definitely not get a vaccine, and another 5% says they probably won't. 
https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2021/04/07/984697573/vaccine-refusal-may-put-herd-immunity-at-risk-researchers-warn
So, somewhere between 0.70 * 217M = 151.9M and 0.75 * 217M = 162.8M is likely to be the ceiling for the number of people who have had at least one vaccine in the near term.  So: 
Without vaccine hesitancy, would expect 162M-165M to have received at least one vaccine dose by the end of the forecast period.
Vaccine hesitancy puts the ceiling approximately in the range 151M-163M. This question really comes down to a different question: what percentage of Americans age 16+ will refuse a vaccine or otherwise not end up getting one? I think I'll need to update this forecast.

Estimate about ~78.0M (or as low as ~75.5M, or a bit higher) more vaccinations administered between now and April 30. Number of vaccinations administered * 0.64 = number of people who have received at least one vaccine dose. 0.64 = (number of people who have received at least one dose) / (number of vaccine doses administered); this number has been pretty constant. To date, 114.4M have received at least one dose. By April 30, then the total should be approximately between 114.4M + 75.5M * 0.64 = 162.7M and 114.4M + 78.0M * 0.64 = 164.3M. This is getting close to the number of people who are expected to get vaccinated, and this estimate is based on current vaccination trends continuing. About a month from now, we may well start running into vaccine hesitancy. About 25% have said they will refuse a vaccine. A recent poll said another 5% are maybes.
https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2021/04/07/984697573/vaccine-refusal-may-put-herd-immunity-at-risk-researchers-warn
An earlier poll found similar results:
https://www.pewresearch.org/science/2021/03/05/growing-share-of-americans-say-they-plan-to-get-a-covid-19-vaccine-or-already-have/ The age 16+ population in the US is about 225M (estimated). If we say 70% of them will take a vaccine, that's 158M. If we say 75% will take a vaccine (and I can't picture it going much higher), that's 169M. Many people have gradually been changing their minds towards taking the vaccine, but at some point soon, we're going to hit a ceiling here in the US.
~112 million right now. Most likely will be a surge after vaccines become available to all adults.

So supply is now in place, and may start to outstrip demand (Forbes: Biden administration officials are anticipating supply will exceed demand in the U.S. by mid-May—if not sooner) (NYTimes: A New Virus Dilemma: How to Handle a Looming Glut of Vaccine). 
From 19th April all age groups will become eligible, but not all 50 states will be included till end of month (Forbes: all 50 states are set to drop their eligibility rules at the beginning of next month). Vaccine hesitancy may also become more of a factor, but I don't see this impacting numbers greatly over a matter of two/three weeks. 
Overall my forecast is for an uptick over two weeks, increasing for the last two weeks - with greater eligibility - up to ~2.0M/day for the remainder.
Total 153-160M with more allowance on the upside.
https://www.forbes.com/sites/jemimamcevoy/2021/04/04/40-of-us-adults-now-vaccinated-but-here-are-all-the-countries-doing-even-better/
https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/26/us/biden-coronavirus-vaccine.html
112 million Americans have received at least one dose as of today and only yesterday more than 3.4 million doses were administered. So I shift towards >170.

On the CDC page, "Daily Change Reported" provides the most current doses/day numbers (better than "Daily Count"), but it's only available for "Total Doses Administered​". Based on the "total doses administered​" current rate of 3 million, which seems to have flatlined, I estimate "People with at least One Dose" rate to be (average) 1.7 million/day in April, and "People Fully Vaccinated" to be 1.3 million/day. 
I extrapolated 1.7 million/day out to 5/4, and also mixed in the crowd forecast, which is higher.

The same trend of 1.6 million a day would put it around 150 million. More doses will be available so I think we're very near to the point where vaccine doses aren't the limiting factor (though more doses will have to go to second doses as well, as the pace of those will have to increase to match the 1.6 million dose per day of first doses over the last month). I think by the end of the month we may be getting to the point where vaccine hesitancy will play the bigger factor. Here's a 538 article about vaccine hesitancy, showing about 20% unlikely to get it and another 20% unsure: https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/more-and-more-americans-say-theyll-get-vaccinated-but-its-still-unclear-just-how-many-will/ And here's another poll showing about the same: https://khn.org/news/article/covid-vaccine-hesitancy-drops-among-americans-new-kff-survey-shows/ With roughly 260 million people over age 16 in the country, if 40% don't jump at the chance to get it that means 156 million might be the number of people who get it before rates drop off and we have to work harder to persuade people to get it. Based on that I'm putting most of the weight around 150 and not a very large tail into the higher numbers.
Not enough clinics  to double the number in a month.
